title: The Teenager with £8 Million
subtitle: Technology genius Marcus Thompson is giving up his mansion and luxury cars to become a student. Emma Clarke asks him why.

cards.text: In the glass-walled conference room of Digital Solutions headquarters in Manchester, there is a sleek metal table. Marcus Thompson is sitting at one end. He is 23 years old and wears an expensive navy suit. The room is brightly lit and his designer glasses catch the light. Under the table, one imagines, his feet barely touch the floor. At first glance, he looks more like a university student who has wandered into a board meeting than a company director worth over £8 million - the youngest self-made millionaire in Britain's tech industry.
cards.question: What is the writer's initial impression of Marcus Thompson?
choices: He is clearly nervous about being interviewed.
His clothing is unsuitable for his age group.
His appearance doesn't match his business success.
He deliberately avoids looking like a typical businessman.
cards.highlight: he looks more like a university student who has wandered into a board meeting than a company director

cards.text: In a few months, he will leave these offices, which have been his entire world since dropping out of school at 17, to attend Oxford University to study law. Digital Solutions, with a workforce of 485 employees and yearly revenue of £75 million, was co-founded by Marcus and his older brother David. While David handles the business strategy, Marcus is the technical genius behind their success. Despite his achievements, Marcus feels he has unfinished business with his education.
cards.question: When the writer asks if he will miss his current lifestyle, Marcus
choices: claims not to understand the question.
admits he might have regrets in the future.
insists it's pointless to miss things.
says he isn't capable of feeling nostalgia.
cards.highlight: admits he might have regrets in the future

cards.text: His goal is to become a qualified lawyer by age 32, and he's unconcerned about earning a modest salary while studying. He wants to learn the intricacies of corporate law properly. His interest in law began in childhood and intensified after dealing with numerous legal contracts at his company. 'I want to understand every clause myself, not rely on expensive lawyers to explain things to me,' he explains.
cards.question: What does Marcus say about his luxury car?
choices: He sold it for less than he paid.
It didn't suit his personality.
It was more expensive than anticipated.
He purchased it to impress others.

cards.text: This autumn, he'll enroll at Oxford, living in regular student accommodation and commuting from a modest flat in Headington, trading his designer suits for jeans and trainers. Marcus smiles when discussing his upcoming student life. 'I'm looking forward to being treated like everyone else. At the company, everyone knows who I am. At university, I'll just be another law student trying to pass exams. It'll be refreshing, honestly.'
cards.question: How does Marcus feel about his future career?
choices: Concerned he may not achieve his objectives.
Confident about how it should progress.
Worried about excessive pressure.
Determined to surpass his business achievements.
cards.highlight: Confident about how it should progress

cards.text: But why abandon the family business during its extraordinary growth? 'There've been moments when I felt people didn't respect me because I work for my brother's company. I need to prove something - mainly to myself. I don't need to be the highest-earning lawyer in London. That's not important to me. But if it happens naturally through good work, I won't complain.'
cards.question: What does 'it' in line 52 refer to?
choices: His legal career.
Partnership at a major firm.
Earning substantial income.
His professional ambitions.
cards.highlight: That's not important to me. But if it happens

cards.text: He refuses credit for the company's success, insisting his brother David's determination made everything possible. 'David is the visionary. Without his drive and business instinct, we'd still be working from our parents' garage. I just write the software - he built the empire.' This modesty seems genuine, though industry analysts credit Marcus's technical innovations as equally crucial to their success.
cards.question: One reason Marcus decided to leave the family company is that
choices: he wants a career people take more seriously.
the company has undergone too many changes.
his family questions his capabilities.
he disagrees with business decisions.
cards.highlight: people didn't respect me because I work for my brother's company

cards.text: Already, his Kensington penthouse is on the market, along with his sports car collection. The money will go into a trust fund for future charitable work. 'Material possessions are overrated,' he reflects. 'They don't bring satisfaction. Learning does. Contributing to society does. Making a real difference in people's lives - that's what matters. And to do that properly in business law, I need the proper education.'
cards.question: What does Marcus say about his brother David?
choices: David sometimes lacks good ideas.
David won't miss Marcus's daily presence.
David might have excelled more in business.
The company succeeded only through David's determination.
cards.highlight: Without his drive and business instinct, we'd still be working from our parents' garage
